description.narrative: The Peacebuilding, Reconciliation and Social Cohesion Project ( PRSCP) (2020-2024)

activity-description.narrative: Support the promotion of peacebuilding and reconciliation at the national level.

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Indicator 1.1.1: Number of peace building and reconciliation policies/frameworks revised and implemented Indicator 1.1.2: Number of Counties implementing the specific county reconciliation plan Indicator 1.1.3. Number of SCORE studies conducted, and policy briefs developed and implemented Indicator 1.2.1. Number of counties with inclusive early warning and response systems for conflict prevention and peace building Indicator 1.2.2.: Number of political dialogues at district, county, and national levels Indicator 1.2.3.: Number of peace structures harmonized and trained with at least 30% women’s participation Indicator 1.2.4: Number of recommendations of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission implemented Indicator 1.3.1: Number of human rights monitors trained to effectively monitor and report on potential human rights abuses and violations, disaggregated by sex Indicator 1.3.2: Number of persons trained to monitor and report on conflict and early warring issues, disaggregated by sex Indicator: 1.3.3: Number of police, justice, security personnel and community watch forum members trained to effectively manage and report cases of violent tendencies, domestic violence, rape and other (in) security threats

comment.narrative: Indicator 1.1.1: Number of peace building and reconciliation policies/frameworks revised and implemented (baseline = 3) Indicator 1.1.2: Number of Counties implementing the specific county reconciliation plan (baseline = 0) Indicator 1.1.3. Number of SCORE studies conducted, and policy briefs developed and implemented (baseline = 2) Indicator 1.2.1. Number of counties with inclusive early warning and response systems for conflict prevention and peace building (baseline = 15) Indicator 1.2.2.: Number of political dialogues at district, county, and national levels (baseline = 2) Indicator 1.2.3.: Number of peace structures harmonized and trained with at least 30% women’s participation (baseline = 12) Indicator 1.2.4: Number of recommendations of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission implemented (baseline = 2) Indicator 1.3.1: Number of human rights monitors trained to effectively monitor and report on potential human rights abuses and violations, disaggregated by sex (baseline = 37 human rights monitors in place) Indicator 1.3.2: Number of persons trained to monitor and report on conflict and early warring issues, disaggregated by sex (baseline = 122 early warning monitors in place) Indicator: 1.3.3: Number of police, justice, security personnel and community watch forum members trained to effectively manage and report cases of violent tendencies, domestic violence, rape and other (in) security threats (baseline = 150)

Target 1.1.1: produce 3 policy briefs Target 1.1.4: Hold a national reconciliation dialogue/conference involving delegates from all 15 counties target 1.2.1: Conduct 3 Palava Hut Hearings for the Mel (Grand Cape Mount), Mende (Bong) & Kwa (River Cess) language groups target 1.2.2: Support implementation of inclusive early warning and response (EWER) mechanism, including the LERN platform for sustained conflict prevention and reconciliation target 1.2.3: Conduct 3 regional political reconciliation dialogues at county level. (three regions) target 1.2.5: Conduct 3 civic engagement town hall meetings involving local leaders and community members on conflict prevention and peacebuilding target 1.2.6. Map and conduct 3 land disputes and boundary harmonization activities and dialogues in conflict prone communities target 1.3.2: Conduct human rights training for 608 personnel involving INCHR human rights officers, the Liberia National Police, justice and security personnel, women as well as community watch forum members on effectively monitoring and reporting of human rights abuses and violations.

Target 1.1.1: No policy briefs were produced due to COVID-19 Target 1.1.4: a national reconciliation dialogue/conference involving delegates from all 7 of the 15 counties was held and the reconciliation action plans were endorsed by stakeholders. A set of resolutions were also endorsed that will guarantee the sustenance of peace in Liberia. Target 1.2.1: Due to lack of sufficient funding only one Palava Hut Hearing was conducted for the Mel language group in Grand Cape Mount. The palava hut hearing is a traditional way of resolving inter-tribal and inter-traditional groups within the same region and community. Target 1.2.2: During the period implementation of inclusive early warning and response (EWER) mechanism, including the LERN platform for sustained conflict prevention and reconciliation was supported through the injection of data to over 150 volunteers of the Early Warning and Early Response and Community Peace Council platforms. Target 1.2.3: The 3 regional political reconciliation dialogues at county level couldnt be held due to inadequacy of funding Target 1.2.5: 5 civic engagement town hall meetings were conducted in Bopolu, Robertsport, Ganta, Gbarnga and Voinjamin and involved local leaders and community members focusing on conflict prevention and peacebuilding Target 1.2.6. One land disputes and boundary harmonization was conducted between Selega and Samadou in Lofa county, there was a mapping of their boundary with cornerstones planted and a welcome signboard erected as a sign of peace and reconciliation between the two communities Target 1.3.2: One human rights training was conducted for 608 personnel involving INCHR human rights officers, the Liberia National Police, justice and security personnel, women as well as community watch forum members on effectively monitoring and reporting of human rights abuses and violations in Ganta City, Nimba County..

Target 1.1: Support the conduct of SCORE wave 3 & 4 with six policy briefs Target 1.2: Review and harmonize the Roadmap and embed the costed 15 county reconciliation plans Target 1.3: At least support existing one peace education (CPE) initiative in selected secondary and tertiary institutions, universities, and local communities Target 2.1 Construct 4 Memorials in Liberia Target 2.2: Conduct 1 palaver hut hearing for the Kwa ethnic group in Rivercess County. Target 2.3: Conduct at least 5 political reconciliation and civic engagement town hall meetings at district levels Target 2.4: Conduct land-based disputes and boundary harmonization activities and dialogues in 2 conflict prone communities of Bong vs Gbarpolu (Jungle James Camp) and Sinoe vs. Rivercess (ITI Community).

Target 1.1: SCORE Wave III 3 was successfully conducted with three policy briefs produced and published including a) a policy brief on Women in Liberia, and reaching equality b) sustaining peace in Liberia, assessing opportunities and threats three years after UNMIL’s departure and c) livelihood resilience and escaping poverty in Liberia, assessing adversities and opportunities for livelihood security
Target 1.2: The roadmap for peace and reconciliation was reviewed and harmonized and embedded in the costed 15 county reconciliation plans at a three-day stakeholders’ dialogue meeting held in Buchanan, Grand Bassa County, May 19 – 21, 2021. Key activities to support sustenance of peace as well as social cohesion were identified and are to be implemented starting 2022 provided funds are available
Target 1.3: One peace education training was conducted for 75 students was conducted targeting 5 universities in Monrovia and Suacoco, Bong County. The universities included: African Methodist Episcopal University (AMEU), African Methodist Episcopal Zion University (AMEZU), United Methodist University (UMU) and University of Liberia (UL) in Monrovia and Cuttington University (CU) in Suacoco, Bong County. The students were trained to mediate and resolve conflicts in their respective schools and communities as well as gathering data and report to the PBO LERN Platform via SMS.
Target 2.1: Four memorials are currently being constructed in four counties in Liberia including Behn Town Memorial in Grand Bassa, Bloh Town Memorial in Rivercess, Bopolu Memorial in Gbarpolu and Kpotomai Memorial in Lofa. The memorials are expected to be completed by January 31, 2022 holding all things constant
Target 2.2: The Kwa ethnic group palava hut hearing was conducted in Central C District, Rivercess County between July 14 – 19, 2021. A total of 49 cases were heard and 48 amicably resolved involving 45 victims ((19 females and 26 males) and 34 perpetrators (2 females and 32 males).
Target 2.3: Conduct at least 5 political reconciliation and civic engagement town hall meetings at district levels. This activity was never done due to COVID-19 restrictions
Target 2.4: Conduct land-based disputes and boundary harmonization activities and dialogues in 2 conflict prone communities of Bong vs Gbarpolu (Jungle James Camp) and Sinoe vs. Rivercess (ITI Community). This activity was never done due to COVID-19 restrictions

1.2: Support implementation of selected 3 activities from the roadmap 2.1: Dedicate 2 and turn over the 4 new memorials 2.2: Conduct one palava hut hearing and resolve 50 cases 2.5: Conduct 2 land disputes and boundary harmonization dialogues
